head.title: Wind River Systems Agrees to Acquisition of ICEsoft

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: Wind River Systems Agrees to Acquisition of ICEsoft

abstract.p: Wind River Systems, maker of software that is embedded in dozens of digital devices, agrees to acquire ICEsoft, Norwegian developer of Web-browsing software for Internet appliances, for $24.5 million (M)

block.p: Wind River Systems, the maker of software that is embedded in dozens of digital devices, will announce today that it has agreed to acquire ICEsoft, a Norwegian developer of Web-browsing software for Internet appliances, for $24.5 million in cash.

The deal will allow Wind River, based in Alameda, Calif., to integrate Internet browsing functions into devices like set-top boxes, digital televisions, Web phones and other devices. Wind River's embedded software powers devices like Sony's Network Walkman NW-E3, Hewlett-Packard's printers and Eastman Kodak's digital cameras. The software is embedded into microchips that are designed by companies like Intel and Hitachi.

Wind River Systems, the maker of software that is embedded in dozens of digital devices, will announce today that it has agreed to acquire ICEsoft, a Norwegian developer of Web-browsing software for Internet appliances, for $24.5 million in cash.

The deal will allow Wind River, based in Alameda, Calif., to integrate Internet browsing functions into devices like set-top boxes, digital televisions, Web phones and other devices. Wind River's embedded software powers devices like Sony's Network Walkman NW-E3, Hewlett-Packard's printers and Eastman Kodak's digital cameras. The software is embedded into microchips that are designed by companies like Intel and Hitachi.

''The era of smart, connected devices is just beginning,'' said Tom St. Dennis, the president and chief executive of Wind River. ''Already millions and every soon billions of devices will be connected to the Internet.

ICEsoft, based in Bergen, Norway, developed a highly popular Web browser for devices with limited computing power called ICE Browser. The program is written in Java, the software standard developed by Sun Microsystems, and supports XML, a type of software coding that will allow for the seamless interchange of all sorts of dynamic data across different computer programs. ICEsoft will continue to operate in Bergen. Wind River has 15 other offices in Europe.
